articles.headline: Accusing Amazon of Antitrust Violations, Authors and Booksellers Demand Inquiry
articles.snippet: Groups representing thousands of authors, agents and independent booksellers are calling for the Department of Justice to examine Amazon.
articles.abstract: Groups representing thousands of authors, agents and independent booksellers are calling for the Department of Justice to examine Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a triumphant moment for Amazon.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Reassess China After Market Free Fall
articles.snippet: The decline comes after a remarkable run-up in share prices, leaving fund managers rethinking their positions and questioning the role of the government.
articles.abstract: The decline comes after a remarkable run-up in share prices, leaving fund managers rethinking their positions and questioning the role of the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long ago that hedge funds were preparing for one of the biggest openings into China in years. In November, foreign investors were for the first time able to buy and sell shares listed in the Shanghai market directly. It was a chance to ride the great China bull run.

articles.headline: ‘Clawbacks’ Could Backfire
articles.snippet: A new rule, which allows payouts to be recovered when the basis of compensation is found to be flawed, is seen having the perverse consequence of driving up salaries further.
articles.abstract: A new rule, which allows payouts to be recovered when the basis of compensation is found to be flawed, is seen having the perverse consequence of driving up salaries further.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clawbacks are coming to corporate America.

articles.headline: Puerto Rico Faces Its Creditors in Early Debt Resolution Talks
articles.snippet: Roughly 350 creditors were told they would have to wait several weeks until a working group of Puerto Rico leaders formed recommendations for resolving the island’s fiscal crisis.
articles.abstract: Roughly 350 creditors were told they would have to wait several weeks until a working group of Puerto Rico leaders formed recommendations for resolving the island’s fiscal crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a meeting on Monday between Puerto Rico and its creditors is any indication, restructuring the island’s $72 billion in debt could be a long process.

articles.headline: A New Look at Apprenticeships as a Path to the Middle Class
articles.snippet: After facing a steep falloff during the recession, apprentice programs are making a comeback, and have caught the notice of students, parents and even some presidential candidates.
articles.abstract: After facing a steep falloff during the recession, apprentice programs are making a comeback, and have caught the notice of students, parents and even some presidential candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. — With its gleaming classrooms, sports teams and even a pep squad, the Apprentice School that serves the enormous Navy shipyard here bears little resemblance to a traditional vocational education program.

articles.headline: Deal Reached on Iran Nuclear Program; Limits on Fuel Would Lessen With Time
articles.snippet: Six world powers agreed to lift sanctions on Iran in exchange for Iranian limits on its nuclear program, but they left open areas sure to raise objections in Congress, like the nation’s ability to produce as much fuel as it wishes after Year 15.
articles.abstract: Six world powers agreed to lift sanctions on Iran in exchange for Iranian limits on its nuclear program, but they left open areas sure to raise objections in Congress, like the nation’s ability to produce as much fuel as it wishes after Year 15.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Iran and a group of six nations led by the United States reached a historic accord on Tuesday to significantly limit Tehran’s nuclear ability for more than a decade in return for lifting international oil and financial sanctions.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Obama’s Leap of Faith on Iran
articles.snippet: President Obama will be long out of office before any reasonable assessment of his effort on Iran’s nuclear program can be made, but the best guess is that the judgment will be mixed.
articles.abstract: President Obama will be long out of office before any reasonable assessment of his effort on Iran’s nuclear program can be made, but the best guess is that the judgment will be mixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — In his opening to China more than 40 years ago, Richard M. Nixon made a huge Cold War gamble that he could forge a working relationship with a Communist country that had built a small arsenal of nuclear weapons and clearly had long-term ambitions for global power.

articles.headline: Republican Lawmakers Vow Fight to Derail Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: Lawmakers have 60 days to scrutinize the accord and then to vote to accept or reject it — or to do nothing.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers have 60 days to scrutinize the accord and then to vote to accept or reject it — or to do nothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Congress had even begun its official review, Republican leaders vowed Tuesday to kill President Obama’s nuclear accord with Iran, setting up a fierce fight to save the president’s signature diplomatic achievement.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Micron Technology Is Said to Be Takeover Target of Chinese Company
articles.snippet: Tsinghua Unigroup, China’s top microchip maker, is preparing a plan to bid $23 billion for the American company, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: Tsinghua Unigroup, China’s top microchip maker, is preparing a plan to bid $23 billion for the American company, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It is either the first step in the largest takeover of an American company by a Chinese one or a new chapter in the emerging technological cold war between the two countries.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Lotte World Tower Rises, and Leery Koreans Watch
articles.snippet: A string of accidents at the 555-meter-tall Lotte World Tower being built in Seoul has drawn intense scrutiny in a country still shaken by the safety failures that led to last year’s ferry disaster.
articles.abstract: A string of accidents at the 555-meter-tall Lotte World Tower being built in Seoul has drawn intense scrutiny in a country still shaken by the safety failures that led to last year’s ferry disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — For people hiking in the hills around Seoul, it is an unmistakable sight: the Lotte World Tower taking shape like a gigantic bamboo shoot.
